posts.cooked:
Most of the following is copied and pasted from Disappearing Messages are retained (i.e. leak) through reply previews · Issue #8787 · signalapp/Signal-Android · GitHub because I essentially got told that this was a feature request, not a bug. I disagree (see below), but I’ll happily play the game if it’ll make sure that my follow-up arguments are heard (since it seems that they weren’t on GitHub) :)

tl;dr: (because I know it’s long, sorry) replies preserve message content even if the original was a disappearing message. This violates principle of least surprise and is dangerous. We should err on the safe side and delete these quoted replies too because there is little downside and potentially a lot of upside. This situation can arise easily if disappearing messages are turned on for one sensitive message and then immediately turned off again.

Essentially the problem is that if a disappearing message is replied to in a non-disappearing message, the disappearing message content is leaked in the reply even after the original is gone.

Steps to reproduce

  1. Set disappearing messages in some conversation to e.g. 5 minutes (it doesn’t really matter)
  2. Send a message
  3. Turn off disappearing messages
  4. Send a new message with the first message set as the message being replied to
  5. Wait for the first message to expire

Actual result: The text and (if applicable) picture of the first, now-disappeared message can be viewed in the reply.

Expected result: The message should be truly gone (note that tapping on the reply does say “original message not available”). I would suggest a “(message disappeared)” placeholder or something but it doesn’t really matter.

According to the Signal developer who responded, this is working as intended because quote-replying a message is like “copying” the message. Here’s my response to that:

@greyson-signal that makes sense now that you say it. However, the problem here is that users understand very well the semantics of copy and paste and they understand that it’s making a copy of the message. That’s not the case with replies because replies - and disappearing messages (and how those features interact) - is not a universally understood UX metaphor. That kind of rich conversation element is too new.

I obviously can’t speak for anyone else, but personally I thought of the reply feature as mostly just referencing an older message. Indeed that’s how it’s presented in the UI: a preview of the “referenced” message is shown and you can tap it to be taken to the full original. I understand that technically that may not be how it works but that’s beside the point - I don’t think it’s at all clear in the UI that these messages will be retained.

(See GitHub for a list of alternatives I thought of and rejected.)

Another argument in favor of making this change is the principle of least surprise: features should behave in a way that is least surprising. I argue that at least some users, possibly many users, will be surprised that disappearing messages do not disappear when quoted in replies. However, I doubt that any user would be surprised if they did disappear in replies, so we should pick the latter since that surprises less users (and errs on the safe side too). Signal is about usable security and it should do the Right Thing™ by default, without users needing to know details like this. (This argument, of course, ignores the code maintainability cost, but I think that’s a small price to pay.)

On GitHub it also became clear that it wasn’t immediately obvious in what situations this would become a problem. However, this is very easy to trigger if (like me) you tend to carry on conversations normally but will turn on disappearing messages for one or two sensitive messages only, and then immediately turn them off again. The disappearing message is natural to quote in a non-disappearing message if it’s the only part of the conversation that’s disappearing.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
It has been stated by the developers quite a few times on this forum that disappearing messages should not be regarded as a safety feature. Signal protects against messages arriving with the wrong people, but if you share messages with someone you can’t trust, that’s your own mistake.

Disappearing messages are only here as a convenience to tidy up the chat. Seeing how other apps do advertise a similar feature as a measure of security, I understand why you assumed it is meant for that cause. Maybe it would make sense to add an additional warning “Disappearing messages do not offer any security, they are merely meant to keep your chat from getting too long over time.”

Please also search the forums, this particular topic has been debated a lot.

Edit:
Let me clarify it this way:
Disappearing messages is a slight misnomer, it is meant to be read as “disappearing message bubbles”. It is about erasing the message bubble, not about erasing the actual message text itself. The message can always linger on the device of a group chat member who hasn’t opened his chat yet. A message simply can’t be securely erased remotely, so this feature can’t be regarded as a security solution anyway.
I agree this doesn’t become apparent from the current in app texts, but that seems to be how it is designed to work.

posts.name: AJ Jordan
posts.cooked: Right, so, let me clarify that I completely understand that disappearing messages doesn’t protect you if you send messages to an untrusted contact. That’s not the expectation here. My understanding of disappearing messages is that the threat model they’re trying to solve is, “I trust my contact to not actively share/save/etc. the message, but I’m worried they’ll forget or not think to actively delete it.” Of course disappearing messages aren’t perfect and there are corner cases like if the contact doesn’t open the message right away. But that doesn’t mean we shouldn’t fix this issue, which again, violates principle of least surprise. I just don’t see huge downsides to making this change, and it seems like an easy usability win (even if the end result still isn’t a “full” solution since that’s obviously impossible).

I don’t see any reason to keep the quoted message around if the original has disappeared, since it’s only a shortened preview and you can’t tap it to see the full text. (And you obviously can’t see the original anymore)

Well, there is actually a reason to keep the quoted message: By quoting, you are explicitly referring to a certain message (thus creating a context for your message). Deleting a quoted message’s preview alongside with the original message would lead to the newer message losing its context…

Quoting disappearing messages should NOT be possible. User must not be able to Copy-Paste, Take Screenshot or Quote it. Disappearing message is and has only one job to do - convey the message and delete itself.

Quoting a disappearing message and replying to it, making the disappeared message visible after it is gone should be deemed a bug. Therefore, it needs to be fixed.

  • Quote / Copy / Screenshot (text should be blacked out like on official documents) options must be DISABLED on the message bubbles. This should be easily achievable by disabling Long-Press on the message bubble that is in actuality of Disappearing type.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
PiCob:

Well, there is actually a reason to keep the quoted message: By quoting, you are explicitly referring to a certain message (thus creating a context for your message). Deleting a quoted message’s preview alongside with the original message would lead to the newer message losing its context …

I guess some people argue that Since the quoted part of the message is always just the first few words, that context is already lost anyway.

So I am thinking, what could in theory happen here:
If I’m in a group chat, and I open the chat and see a disappearing message. Now I have seen it, the time will start running for me. I leave the chat, and don’t reopen it for a while. When I come back into the chat that dosappearing message is long gone, but someone quoted it to reply to it.

  • if the quote would be deleted, than I don’t can’t see what message is being quoted
  • if the quote would still show the first words of the message, at least i have a chance to recall which message this is refering to.

So although I don’t like it, I have to admit @PiCob has a point. There are scenarios where the quoted reply cannot honor disappearing messages, because the message might have disappearded for me but someone else migbt still try quote repy to it. I woudn’t get any context.

I am also thinking about the future of quoted messages. I have written a feature request, to request that we can quote selected segments of previous messages. Quote/reply to selected characters (only a part of the message text)
If something like that gets implemented in the future, than the context which quotes provide becomes even more relevant. That means that removing the qupted text can seriously derail the conversation, because some people in a group might not be able to see the same context as others.

Keep in mind messages timers start when you have seen the message, so in a group the messages don’t disappear at the same time for everyone.

I think deleting the text from the original messsage is not worth the chance that conversations will lose context. Furthermore, if you trust participants of the chat you are in, you can also trust them to not abuse quotes on purpose, and if they happen to quote a very sensitive message just after you turn of dosappearing message timers, than you can always ask them to delete it manually.

There are two different solutions I can think off, both of which you could write a feature request for:

  • feature: add a button to propose to all members of the conversation to delete message history up till a certain message.
  • feature: make disappearing messages unquotable if the disappearing message timer had been turned off, or if the disappearing message timer has been set to a much longer time interval.

I for one don’t need a solution to this issue, but if you wish to continue to find one msybe one of those features could help for you.

awaitlink:

What if you’re using disappearing messages just for cleaning up your chat, with timer set to 1 week? Then access to message information might be needed.

Furthermore, try telling someone: “ if you enable this feature, you’ll lose access to some basic features of Signal ”. Will they use this feature? I doubt it.

Setting in the settings to truncate messages after pre-set period of time deals with that. Abusing disappearing messages for that is just that…abuse of a poorly formulated feature.

Disappearing messages are for things you don’t want to remain within the active message list with that particular person…sort of off-the-off-the-record. And timers longer than 3 seconds from receipt should not be possible to set. It breaks the intent behind the disappearing messages which is a “blip on the radar”. Unless the person is prepared with cameras and everything…practicality of being prepared all the time to record such a message is less and less.

  • No Quoting
  • No Screenshot for Disappearing messages
  • No Copy-Paste
  • No Forwarding
  • No Info
  • Not recorded in backup
  • No AndroidQ Smart Replies

Having all of that should be considered a bug and breaking the intent behind the Disappearing Messages. Should not be mixed up and confused with the Deleting Old Messages After XX

awaitlink:

Also, e.g. if you are assisting your non-tech-savvy friend, they might send you a password using Signal via a disappearing message with 5s/10s timer. But you assisted them in creating this password earlier, so it’s 32 characters. Unless you can type 6.4/3.2 chars/sec or have a really really good memory, how are you going to enter the password?

Just send an ordinary E2EE Signal message and delete it afterwards. The person that helped set up the account already knows the account information, so using disappearing message to transport account infor is an unecessary complexity in the transaction.

jeremymasters:

But that is not the intent at all. It’s for cleanliness.

Self-destructing messages appeared first (as far as I know) in Snapchat. The point there was to prevent having history of ridiculous images and they were also first to implement screenshot prevention and notification if screenshot was taken in the contemporary messengers.
I think other messengers copied that from them because of that…otherwise there really is no point, because that setting could have been placed in the settings next to backup and number limit, called Fading messages (messages fade away after a pre-set period of time).
Makes more sense than calling it Disappearing messages or even Self-Destructing messages. Having it separate from settings makes it look like a feature that is intended for single-message use similarily to Snapchat’s “kinky/ridiculous” message deletion type of thing.

Now, choose your design. It is either or. There is no mixing these two types of use.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: The word “fading” usually describes a loss of opacity. The messages in a thread with this setting do not fade, but instead instantly vanish from a device. My take is that this is both the intended and functional process. What you use it for is up to you. They advertise it for thread cleanliness. You can use it to take over the world if you’d like.
